thread.title: Good news for Cowboys: NFC East isn't very good
thread.title_full: Good news for Cowboys: NFC East isn't very good

title: Good news for Cowboys: NFC East isn't very good
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Good news for Cowboys: NFC East isn't very good The Cowboys have hope that they can turn their injury-riddled season around thanks to a weak NFC East Post to Facebook Good news for Cowboys: NFC East isn't very good The Cowboys have hope that they can turn their injury-riddled season around thanks to a weak NFC East   WFAA.com: http://on.wfaa.com/1RWYicu   Join the Conversation To   Good news for Cowboys: NFC East isn't very good Andrew Tobolowsky, WFAA Sports 5:20 p.m. CDT October 21, 2015 The Cowboys have hope that they can turn their injury-riddled season around thanks to a weak NFC East A general view as the Dallas Cowboys play against the New England Patriots (Photo: Erich Schlegel, Erich Schlegel-USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Just like last year, it's now clear that the Eagles are the Cowboys' biggest competition for the NFC East. Unlike last year, both the Eagles and the Cowboys are not very good. But the Cowboys, at least when healthy, have a chance to be very good. It's therefore a race to see how fast they can get healthy. 
This week, the Cowboys play the Giants, who were taken apart by the Eagles last week. The Eagles attack featured one thing the Cowboys hope to have---pressure on the QB—and one thing they used to have. DeMarco Murray broke out of his slump, rushing for 110 yards and a touchdown. As far as the Cowboys are concerned, that's bad news. 
The good news for the Cowboys is that as bad as Eli Manning was, Sam Bradford was probably a little worse. His 24 completions went for nearly 100 more yards than Eli's 24, but he had 3 INTs to Eli's 2. That's something the Cowboys can work with. It's starting to look like either Brandon Weeden or Matt Cassell may be, at least, not much worse than the guy helming their biggest divisional challenge. Not that Sam doesn't have more in the way of gifts than either of the Cowboys' QBs but right now his YPA and TD: INT ratio look just about the same. 
And this is where this weekend's game comes in. Wouldn't it be something if the major difference between a team which swung a big QB trade and signed the offseason's top RB and a team which had no established RB and its top two offensive options injured by the second game of the season, was defense? 
What the Eagles did to the Giants last Sunday is exactly what the Cowboys hope to be able to do this Sunday. With the likes of Greg Hardy, Sean Lee, Tyrone Crawford, DeMarcus Lawrence, and others—including a returning Randy Gregory , the Cowboys have all the tools to harass Manning into the same bad throws he made last week. Whether they will, against a guy who seems to be tough against the Cowboys even in his bad seasons, is another question. 
But if they can, and if they do, it will go a long way to answering the question of whether the Cowboys can stay afloat in the NFC East until they get back some of the pieces they're missing on offense. It's not the season anybody expected, but it can still come out alright. 
Read more from Andrew on the Cowboys and Dallas Mavericks on Twitter @andytobo . Read or Share this story: http://on.wfaa.com/1RWYicu TOP VIDEOS
